To the Stockholders of Berkshire Hathaway Inc:

Operating earnings in 1977 of $21,904,000, or $22.54 per share, were moderately better than anticipated a year ago. Of these earnings, $1.43 per share resulted from substantial realized capital gains by Blue Chip Stamps which, to the extent of our proportional interest in that company, are included in our operating earnings figure. Capital gains or losses realized directly by Berkshire Hathaway Inc. or its insurance subsidiaries are not included in our calculation of operating earnings. While too much attention should not be paid to the figure for any single year, over the longer term the record regarding aggregate capital gains or losses obviously is of significance.
contextual_summary: This chunk provides an overview of Berkshire Hathaway's operating earnings for 1977, highlighting a modest improvement over the previous year. Buffett notes the contribution of capital gains from Blue Chip Stamps to these earnings while emphasizing the importance of long-term performance over single-year figures.
next_context: Textile operations came in well below forecast, while the results of the Illinois National Bank as well as the operating earnings attributable to our equity interest in Blue Chip Stamps were about as anticipated.

chunk_text: Textile operations came in well below forecast, while the results of the Illinois National Bank as well as the operating earnings attributable to our equity interest in Blue Chip Stamps were about as anticipated. However, insurance operations, led again by the truly outstanding results of Phil Liesches managerial group at National Indemnity Company, were even better than our optimistic expectations.
contextual_summary: This chunk discusses the performance of various business segments within Berkshire Hathaway in 1977, noting that textile operations fell short of expectations while insurance operations exceeded them, particularly due to the performance of National Indemnity Company.

chunk_text: Most companies define record earnings as a new high in earnings per share. Since businesses customarily add from year to year to their equity base, we find nothing particularly noteworthy in a management performance combining, say, a 10% increase in equity capital and a 5% increase in earnings per share. After all, even a totally dormant savings account will produce steadily rising interest earnings each year because of compounding.
contextual_summary: This chunk critiques the common practice of defining record earnings solely by earnings per share, arguing that such measures can be misleading. Buffett emphasizes the importance of considering equity capital growth and the compounding effect in evaluating managerial performance.

chunk_text: Except for special cases (for example, companies with unusual debt-equity ratios or those with important assets carried at unrealistic balance sheet values), we believe a more appropriate measure of managerial economic performance to be return on equity capital. In 1977 our operating earnings on beginning equity capital amounted to 19%, slightly better than last year and above both our own long-term average and that of American industry in aggregate. But, while our operating earnings per share were up 37% from the year before, our beginning capital was up 24%, making the gain in earnings per share considerably less impressive than it might appear at first glance.
contextual_summary: This chunk discusses the importance of return on equity capital as a measure of managerial performance, revealing that Berkshire Hathaway's operating earnings on beginning equity capital were 19% in 1977. Buffett highlights the disparity between earnings per share growth and capital growth, suggesting that the latter diminishes the apparent success of the former.

chunk_text: The textile business again had a very poor year in 1977. We have mistakenly predicted better results in each of the last two years. This may say something about our forecasting abilities, the nature of the textile industry, or both. Despite strenuous efforts, problems in marketing and manufacturing have persisted. Many difficulties experienced in the marketing area are due primarily to industry conditions, but some of the problems have been of our own making.
contextual_summary: This chunk reflects on the poor performance of the textile business in 1977, acknowledging past mispredictions and ongoing issues in marketing and manufacturing. Buffett suggests that both external industry conditions and internal management issues have contributed to these challenges.

chunk_text: A few shareholders have questioned the wisdom of remaining in the textile business which, over the longer term, is unlikely to produce returns on capital comparable to those available in many other businesses. Our reasons are several: (1) Our mills in both New Bedford and Manchester are among the largest employers in each town, utilizing a labor force of high average age possessing relatively non-transferable skills. Our workers and unions have exhibited unusual understanding and effort in cooperating with management to achieve a cost structure and product mix which might allow us to maintain a viable operation.
contextual_summary: This chunk addresses shareholder concerns about the textile business's viability, outlining reasons for remaining in the industry. Buffett emphasizes the mills' role as major employers and the cooperation of workers and unions in maintaining operations despite challenges.

chunk_text: Our insurance operation continued to grow significantly in 1977. It was early in 1967 that we made our entry into this industry through the purchase of National Indemnity Company and National Fire and Marine Insurance Company (sister companies) for approximately $8.6 million. In that year their premium volume amounted to $22 million. In 1977 our aggregate insurance premium volume was $151 million. No additional shares of Berkshire Hathaway stock have been issued to achieve any of this growth.
contextual_summary: This chunk outlines the significant growth of Berkshire Hathaway's insurance operations in 1977, detailing the initial acquisition of National Indemnity Company and the substantial increase in premium volume from $22 million in 1967 to $151 million in 1977.

chunk_text: In aggregate, the insurance business has worked out very well. But it hasnt been a one-way street. Some major mistakes have been made during the decade, both in products and personnel. We experienced significant problems from (1) a surety operation initiated in 1969, (2) the 1973 expansion of Home and Automobiles urban auto marketing into the Miami, Florida area, (3) a still unresolved aviation fronting arrangement, and (4) our Workers Compensation operation in California, which we believe retains an interesting potential upon completion of a reorganization now in progress.
contextual_summary: This chunk reflects on the overall success of Berkshire Hathaway's insurance business while acknowledging past mistakes in operations and personnel. Buffett lists specific challenges faced, including issues with a surety operation and urban auto marketing.

next_context: It is comforting to be in a business where some mistakes can be made and yet a quite satisfactory overall performance can be achieved. In a sense, this is the opposite case from our textile business where even very good management probably can average only modest results.

chunk_text: One of the lessons your management has learned - and, unfortunately, sometimes re-learned - is the importance of being in businesses where tailwinds prevail rather than headwinds. In 1977 the winds in insurance underwriting were squarely behind us. Very large rate increases were effected throughout the industry in 1976 to offset the disastrous underwriting results of 1974 and 1975. But, because insurance policies typically are written for one-year periods, with pricing mistakes capable of correction only upon renewal, it was 1977 before the full impact was felt upon earnings of those earlier rate increases.
contextual_summary: This chunk discusses the importance of being in favorable business conditions, highlighting the positive impact of rate increases in the insurance industry in 1977. Buffett notes that the benefits of these increases were only fully realized in 1977 due to the nature of insurance policy renewals.

next_context: The pendulum now is beginning to swing the other way. We estimate that costs involved in the insurance areas in which we operate rise at close to 1% per month.

chunk_text: The pendulum now is beginning to swing the other way. We estimate that costs involved in the insurance areas in which we operate rise at close to 1% per month. This is due to continuous monetary inflation affecting the cost of repairing humans and property, as well as social inflation, a broadening definition by society and juries of what is covered by insurance policies. Unless rates rise at a comparable 1% per month, underwriting profits must shrink.
contextual_summary: This chunk warns of the impending challenges in the insurance industry as costs are expected to rise due to inflation. Buffett emphasizes the need for rates to keep pace with these rising costs to maintain underwriting profitability.

next_context: Recently the pace of rate increases has slowed dramatically, and it is our expectation that underwriting margins generally will be declining by the second half of the year.
